segments.text: Hi, I'm Kendall Binion.
Current doctoral candidates at the University of Wyoming Clinical Psychology program.

This is such a big important topic to talk about because adolescent depression affects so many people and it affects so many different aspects of people's lives, such as with family, friends, work, school and so much more.

And that's that evidence based treatment, which pretty much means that research shows that it works. So what is depression and how do you know if you or a loved one or your teen has depression or is just going through something? That kind of looks like it.

And depression can look very different for each person. It's very individualized. Uh, no, actually, as I just said, treatment usually lasts six to 20 sessions. But here in our clinic, it's actually kind of even smaller. Usually sessions last 12 to 15 sessions, usually meeting about 50 minutes once a week. So, you know, it's very manageable. It's time oriented.

And for the clinician, it's also very effective because we're having to constantly re evaluate and look at the progress that the client is making to make sure that they're on the right track and meeting that kind of deadline and that, you know, time push.
Yeah. And with that kind of goal oriented, you know, direction that CBT has, one of the things that we also like to do with CBT is assign homework.

In this assessment period, there are two main goals. Also understanding the symptoms well enough to have an effective plan for therapy. But how long until the client's feeling better all the way?
So, I know one of the big questions that I'm sure we all have going through our heads right now is, how does CBT relate to medication?

Generally, though, CBT provides the same amount of relief as medication, but we're not having the same kind of negative physiological side effects that often accompany medication. So, you know, in other words, CBT tends to be just as effective without kind of having those negative physiological, you know, just bodily reactions that sometimes accompany medication.
Yeah, that's right. So CBT allows for kind of treating that root cause of depression, and so where medication doesn't really allow that.

And so even though medication can work quickly to kind of alleviate symptoms, usually once people start taking that medication, the depressive symptoms can return. And so overall, CBT is better at kind of reducing those possible relapses that is often accompanied with medication use.

And there's a lot of different ways to go about finding a therapist in your area. One of the easiest ways is just to Google Search ABCT Therapists, which stands for the association for Behavioral and Cognitive Therapists at Therapies. And just look for their website.

Additionally, you know, you can contact your insurance provider and see if there's any therapists in your area who practice cbt. There's other factors to consider when trying to find and choose a therapist in your area, but most importantly, make sure. That they're licensed in your area.
